awd_titl_txt: RUI: Photoisomerization Potential of Molecular Switches on Surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Andreas Riemann of Western Washington University (WWU) is supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program of the Division of Chemistry to investigate the behavior of spiropyran molecular switches.  A molecular switch is a molecule that can swing back and forth between two or more stable states. In each state, the molecule has a distinctive shape, structure, and electronic and optical properties.  The molecules switch from one state to another in response to external stimuli, such as light.  The goal is to control the switching mechanism and create surface structures consisting of functional molecular switches.  Molecular switches are important components of molecular electronics used in electronic devices.  Undergraduate students at WWU are an integral part of this project and are given relevant experiences for their futures in scientific research or in industry. Additionally, Professor Riemann is involved in outreach through "Compass 2 Campus," a Western Washington University initiative to increase science literacy of students from traditionally underrepresented backgrounds, by stimulating their interest in research and providing them with pathways to higher education.   

The goal of this research is to study molecule/substrate combinations which are able to undergo a photoisomerization process with a large enough cross-section to make it suitable for further application in molecular electronics. The systems under investigation are spiropyran/merocyanine isomers deposited on noble metal substrates and graphite. Thin molecular films where individual molecules can be excited to switch their configuration are created. Conformational behavior of these molecules and control of the photoisomerization process are investigated using a variety of experimental surface science techniques such as STM, LEED and XPS as well as computational chemistry methods including DFT and Molecular Mechanics calculations.  The project is conducted in three stages: 1) the analysis of adsorption behavior of various spiropyran-based molecules at various temperatures and substrate coverages; 2) the use of light and heat to trigger and monitor isomerization switching; and 3) the use of computational chemistry to simulate the adsorption behavior of spiropyran-based isomers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The project involved the investigation of molecular switches. These molecular switches can be used in the potential application of molecular electronics where structural, electronic and optical properties can be activated by external stimuli such as light or heat.

One class of molecules investigated in this project are spiropyran molecules where a central bond can be broken, and this molecule transforms into a merocyanine molecule. The back reaction would re-establish this molecular bond and re-create the spiropyran molecule.

In order to be useful in the field of molecular electronics these molecules need to be anchored to a suitable substrate. The properties of this adsorption process was investigated for this project. it was found that merocyanine molecules can adsorb in a film-like, ordered fashion on substrates with different electronic properties themselves. The binding of these merocyanine molecules has been found to be stronger than their partner spiropyran molecules due to higher cross-sectional areas of adsorption. The nature of the merocyanine molecules allows in principle various configurations which amount to different chirality of the molecule. However, when adsorbed on substrates one subset of molecular chirality is suppressed and only the other subset can adsorb energetically favorable on these substrates.

In order to accomplish a switching of these molecules from merocyanine to spiropyran and vice versa, the effect of the substrate adsorption has to be taken into account. It was found that the stronger adsorption of merocyanine to many substrates means that the switching mechanism to spiropyran is energetically hindered and requires higher energies. This process, though, can be accomplished by heating of the system which encourages partly desorption, bond re-establishing, and then re-adsorption onto the substrate. On the other hand, switching from spiropyran to merocyanine requires a lower energy amount, since the adsorption process is easier to succeed.

These findings provide a stepping stone of further develop and analyze molecular system capable of being used in the field of molecular electronics.

During the whole project, undergraduate students from Western Washington university, a predominantly undergraduate institution, have been involved in all aspects. This included carrying out experimental and computational work, data analysis, and the dissemination of the results. Their experience in this work has prepared them for a successful scientific career after graduation in a wide variety of fields including physical sciences, data analysis etc.


Last Modified: 08/04/2023
Modified by: Andreas Riemann
